title: Turn Off Compatibility Mode in Microsoft Word in 4 Easy Steps

steps.title: Open your document in Word.
steps.content: Open your document in Word. If a single document opened in Compatibility Mode, you can exit this mode by saving the document in a newer file format. You can either open your document within Word from the “File” tab, or you can find your file in your file browser, right-click on it, then select “Open With…” and “Word.” [1] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source This method will work on the version of Word that comes with Microsoft 365, Word 2021, Word 2019, and Word 2016.

steps.title: Click the File tab.
steps.content: Click the File tab. You'll find this either above your document space on the left side of the window (Windows) or along the top of your screen (Macs). [2] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Info.
steps.content: Click Info . More options will open to the right. [3] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Convert.
steps.content: Click Convert . The document will convert to the newer version of Word. You might lose your layout, font, or features by converting. [4] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source If you don't see this option, go to File > Save As . If you're using Microsoft 365 for Windows, click Browse next. Select Word Document (*.docx) from the "Save as type" or "File Format" menu. If you see an option to "Maintain compatibility with previous versions of Word," remove the checkmark from the box. Click Save to convert your document to the DOCX format.

steps.title: Click the File tab.
steps.content: Click the File tab. You'll find this at the top-left corner of the window.

steps.title: Click Options.
steps.content: Click Options . More options will open.

steps.title: Click the Save tab.
steps.content: Click the Save tab. It's on the left panel.

steps.title: Select "Word Document (*.docx)" as the default saving format.
steps.content: Select "Word Document (*.docx)" as the default saving format. This option is in the "Save files in this format" menu.

steps.title: Click OK.
steps.content: Click OK . Going forward, you will be able to create and save files without going into Compatibility Mode. Try creating a new document and saving it in Word. If it still goes into Compatibility Mode, continue to the next step.

steps.title: Disable the compatibility checker.
steps.content: Disable the compatibility checker. If the previous steps didn't work, try this: Click the File tab and select Info . Click Check for issues . Click Check Compatibility . Uncheck "Check compatibility when saving documents" and click OK .

steps.title: Click the Word menu.
steps.content: Click the Word menu. It's in the menu bar at the top of the screen.

steps.title: Click Preferences.
steps.content: Click Preferences . This opens your Word preferences. [5] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Save.
steps.content: Click Save . You'll see this under "Output and Sharing."

steps.title: Select "Microsoft Word Document (*.docx)" from the "Save Word files as" menu.
steps.content: Select "Microsoft Word Document (*.docx)" from the "Save Word files as" menu. If this menu was set to a different file type, changing it to DOCX will ensure you can create and save files without activating Compatibility Mode. Try creating a new document and saving it in Word. If it still goes into Compatibility Mode, continue to the next step.

steps.title: Disable the compatibility checker.
steps.content: Disable the compatibility checker. If the previous steps didn't work for you, give this a try: Click the Word menu and select Preferences . Under "Output and sharing," click Compatibility report . Deselect "Check documents for compatibility."
